title: Middleware breaks OpenAPI YAML
Typia Openapi generator : feature request
body:
Hi,

I have a feature request for a new Typia OpenAPI/Swagger generator middleware, similar to hono/zod-openapi. 
Typia is significantly faster than Zod for input validation, as demonstrated in this [benchmark](https://dev.to/samchon/typescript-json-is-10-1000x-times-faster-than-zod-and-io-ts-8n6).

Currently, the Hono Typia middleware lacks an OpenAPI generator, which limits its practical usage. Integrating this feature would greatly enhance the ease of creating APIs with Typia and make Hono APIs even faster.

To aid in this integration, the following projects can be referenced:

- Typia NestJS OpenAPI Generator:

   [Typia NestJS OpenAPI Generator](https://github.com/samchon/nestia/tree/db4ce37cc3e99b5920d9267a00cecfee495efe74/packages/sdk/src/generates)

   This package has already implemented a similar functionality for NestJS.

- Typia OpenAPI Converter:

   [Typia OpenAPI Converter](https://github.com/samchon/openapi)

It would be fantastic to see a similar feature added to Hono. This enhancement would streamline the development process and leverage Typia's speed for ultra-fast Hono APIs.

Thank you for considering this request.

title: chore: Update valibot to version 0.31.0
body:
## Overview

Update valibot to version 0.31.0.
**0.31.0 will lose backward compatibility due to many breaking changes.**

0.31.0 has not yet been officially released. Therefore, it is a draft PR.

## Details

Changes have been made to correspond to the changes in 0.31.0.

From 0.31.0, the pipe function, which was previously built-in, is now defined as an independent function. This means that each API was able to perform consecutive validations on the second and third arguments, but from 0.31.0 validations will be performed using an independent pipe function.

https://github.com/fabian-hiller/valibot/pull/502

```ts
// 0.30.0 or lower
number("required", [minValue(1, "min"), maxValue(10, "max")])
// 0.31.0 or higher
pipe(number("required"), minValue(1, "min"), maxValue(10, "max"))
```

Also, from 0.31.0 onwards there will be a change in the type definition name.

https://valibot.dev/guides/migrate-from-v0.30.0/

title: hono-openapi expects `method` parameter to be of a specific type
body:
After upgrading to v0.14.0, all of my routes suddenly exploded with errors related to `method` needing to be of type `Method`.

![image](https://github.com/honojs/middleware/assets/17836372/51bdb4fc-1026-4e4c-babf-c77bfa3ea117)
```
 Types of property 'method' are incompatible.
      Type 'string' is not assignable to type 'Method'.ts(2345)
```

AFAIK, the Method type is not exported from `hono-openapi`, so there isn't any way to satisfy this type constraint. Previously, simply using a string worked fine.

The method type is fairly straight-forward, so I'm not sure why this error is occuring now:
```ts
type Method = 'get' | 'post' | 'put' | 'delete' | 'patch' | 'head' | 'options' | 'trace';
```

Strangely, Hono exports the `METHODS` array, which can be used and it satisfies the Typescript analysis:
![image](https://github.com/honojs/middleware/assets/17836372/2d1140d7-8237-4d95-8423-b6da3cdea5f8)

However, this is suboptimal because now the actual method is hidden within the array value.

title: behind a reverse proxy, X-Forwarded-Proto isn't used and plain http is used for the signin action
body:
I'm running deno behind an apache2 (reverse proxy).  SSL is terminated at the apache2 and it uses plain http to communicate with the deno server.

The system I'm migrating from worked with: `RequestHeader set X-Forwarded-Proto "https"` but this middleware doesn't seem to notice this header, the /api/auth/signin page ends up containing:

```
<form action="http://betatest.mydomain.com/api/auth/signin/google" method="POST">
  <input type="hidden" name="csrfToken" value="8dc4c49dfe160f6a9737d67af01f22e42ba9e71adc7d55ebeecbd57c6076fb15">
  <input type="hidden" name="callbackUrl" value="http://betatest.mydomain.com">
```

I found that I could open the dev console and edit the element to just change that first http to https and then it submits without a warning.

I've got environment vars like so:

```
AUTH_TRUST_HOST=true
AUTH_URL=https://betatest.mydomain.com/api/auth/signin
```

But these apparently aren't enough to do it (the Auth.js docs seem to be saying the second one isn't needed).

Is there some way I'm missing to get https to be used here?

title: [zod-openapi]- running middleware after validation
body:
I'm migrating the app from `Hono` to `OpenAPIHono` however I have stumbled upon a problem.

I have an `auth` middleware that runs before the final handler
```ts
export const usersRouter = new Hono()

usersRouter.post("/user-subscription", auth, userSubscription)
```
`auth` middleware is looking at the `request.headers` and it's deciding if it should proceed with the execution, it creates a `sesssion` for the downstream middleware to use.

The idea is that we check for the `headers`(needed for `auth`) via the validators in the `openAPI` spec, and if we have the correct headers then we run the `auth` middleware , and then the final handler.

 With `OpenAPIHono` this is not possible.
 
The problem with `OpenAPIHono` is that the middleware runs **before** the validators.
What is the reasoning behind that decision?

Ideally, we should run **validators** first , then run the middleware. If we can pass the `validation` stage then we know that we have a valid request.

Middleware that deals with business logic **before** validation is not usable.

feat(trpc-server): use c.body to create response to avoid header loss
body:
in `trpc-server` middleware, we currently return the response directly which causes the respose to loose information about context. So if we set a header/cookie inside a trpc route, we don't get that in the respose.

I have fixed it by creating a new response object with `c.body` and returning that.

A reproduction of the issue can be found at https://github.com/BlankParticle/hono-header-reproduction/tree/main

body:
## Problem 

When using `@hono/sentry` along with the newer `cloudflare:test` / [Vitest integration](https://developers.cloudflare.com/workers/testing/vitest-integration/), I get an error:

```console
Error: `require()` is not yet implemented in Workers.
Attempted to `require("toucan-js")` from "file:///[REDACTED]/node_modules/@hono/sentry/dist/index.js"
    at [REDACTED]/node_modules/@cloudflare/vitest-pool-workers/dist/worker/lib/node/module.mjs:8:20
    at /[REDACTED]/node_modules/@hono/sentry/dist/index.js:4:21
    at VitestExecutor.runModule ([REDACTED]/node_modules/vite-node/dist/client.mjs:362:11)
    at VitestExecutor.runModule ([REDACTED]/node_modules/vitest/dist/vendor/execute.aFSzc0Da.js:549:20)
    at VitestExecutor.directRequest ([REDACTED]/node_modules/vite-node/dist/client.mjs:346:16)
    at VitestExecutor.cachedRequest ([REDACTED]/node_modules/vite-node/dist/client.mjs:189:14)
    at VitestExecutor.dependencyRequest ([REDACTED]/node_modules/vite-node/dist/client.mjs:233:12)
    at /[REDACTED]/src/middleware/sentry.ts:1:154
    at VitestExecutor.runModule ([REDACTED]/node_modules/vite-node/dist/client.mjs:362:5)
    at VitestExecutor.directRequest ([REDACTED]/node_modules/vite-node/dist/client.mjs:346:5)
 ❯ [REDACTED]/node_modules/@cloudflare/vitest-pool-workers/dist/worker/lib/node/module.mjs:8:20
 ❯ node_modules/@hono/sentry/dist/index.js:4:21
      2| Object.defineProperty(exports, "__esModule", { value: true });
      3| exports.getSentry = exports.sentry = void 0;
      4| const toucan_js_1 = require("toucan-js");
       |                     ^
      5| class MockContext {
      6|     passThroughOnException() {
 ❯ src/middleware/sentry.ts:1:154
 ❯ [REDACTED]/node_modules/@cloudflare/vitest-pool-workers/dist/worker/lib/node/module.mjs:9:11
 ❯ node_modules/@hono/sentry/dist/index.js:4:21
 ❯ src/middleware/sentry.ts:1:154
```

Here are some notable dependecies:
```jsonc
// package.json; (trimmed)
  "dependencies": {
    "@hono/sentry": "^1.0.1",
    "hono": "^4.0.1",
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@cloudflare/vitest-pool-workers": "https://prerelease-registry.devprod.cloudflare.dev/workers-sdk/runs/8850920915/npm-package-cloudflare-vitest-pool-workers-5508",
    "@vitest/coverage-v8": "1.3.0",
    "@vitest/ui": "1.3.0",
    "vite-tsconfig-paths": "^4.3.1",
    "vitest": "1.3.0",
    "wrangler": "https://prerelease-registry.devprod.cloudflare.dev/workers-sdk/prs/5508/npm-package-wrangler-5508"
  }
```

## Proposed solution

Update `@hono/sentry` with ESM support.

I believe there was a similar issue with `@hono/zod-openapi`: https://github.com/honojs/middleware/issues/436. Linking some related work in [`asteasolutions/zod-to-openapi`](https://github.com/asteasolutions/zod-to-openapi/commit/732f52b4cbc3f7d0df661626bfed394e5faaee42#diff-47407fecafdf5f5cd55403c3de457833ddf9b6fab45253c04e1dc4c7cb4495b1)

For `@hono/sentry` and I think `toucan-js` already supports ESM[^1], so this might be an easy fix? 🤞  
[^1]:https://github.com/robertcepa/toucan-js/blob/master/packages/toucan-js/package.json#L7-L8

[Trpc Server + Cors] The 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header contains multiple values 'http://localhost:3000, *', but only one is allowed
Sentry middleware captures HTTPException
body:
Hello! We are throwing an HTTPException in our code. hono/sentry captures this and creates an event in Sentry:

![image](https://github.com/honojs/middleware/assets/3639540/79b33560-96b3-4fa7-9d1b-f75896206633)

Is this the expected behavior? To me it seems that HTTPException shouldn't be captured, since it's actually a "handled" exception, in the sense that we are returning it manually (as an "escape-hatch") because we _expect_ it to occur.

title: fix(auth-js): env AUTH_URL not working
body: In the previous implementation, `AUTH_URL` was invalid because `c.req.raw` already includes the URL base. The provided URL base, `c.env.AUTH_URL`, will not be utilized. This issue will prevent the hono + auth.js project deployed behind a proxy from obtaining the correct `callback-url`.

body:
I'm trying to use honojs with react on cloudflare-pages. After install the `npm i @hono/react-renderer` package and update `tsconfig.json` to react as below got an error. 

*tsconfig.json* file
```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ESNext",
    "module": "ESNext",
    "moduleResolution": "Bundler",
    "strict": true,
    "lib": [
      "ESNext"
    ],
    "types": [
      "@cloudflare/workers-types",
      "vite/client"
    ],
    "jsx": "react-jsx",
    "jsxImportSource": "react"
  },
}
```

`vite.config.ts` file
```typescript
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react'
import build from '@hono/vite-cloudflare-pages'
import devServer from '@hono/vite-dev-server'
import adapter from '@hono/vite-dev-server/cloudflare'
import { defineConfig } from 'vite'

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [
    react(),
    build(),
    devServer({
      adapter,
      entry: 'src/index.tsx'
    })
  ]
})
```

*renderer.tsx* file
```typescript
import { reactRenderer } from '@hono/react-renderer'

export const renderer = reactRenderer(({ children, title }) => {
  return (
    <html>
      <head>
        <link href="/static/style.css" rel="stylesheet" />
        <title>{title}</title>
      </head>
      <body>{children}</body>
    </html>
  )
})
```

Node version:
`v21.7.1`

The error information after I run `npm run dev`:
```shell
5:03:35 PM [vite] Error when evaluating SSR module src/index.tsx: failed to import "/node_modules/react/jsx-dev-runtime.js"
|- ReferenceError: module is not defined
    at eval (/Users/admin/Documents/project/memsight/node_modules/react/jsx-dev-runtime.js:8:3)

```

title: Upgrade to Clerk Core 2
body:
Clerk Core 2 is now generally available, the Clerk Hono middleware package can now be upgraded.

The current version of the package is not compatible with the new Clerk Core 2.

title: clerk-auth: Migrate to Clerk Core v2
body:
Yesterday [Clerk Core v2](https://clerk.com/docs/upgrade-guides/core-2/overview) was released.

This PR updates the `clerk-auth` middleware to use the new version of Clerk Backend API.

I updated the middleware according to the [official Clerk's migration guide](https://clerk.com/docs/upgrade-guides/core-2/backend), as well as the tests (based on the [Clerk's Fastify middleware](https://github.com/clerk/javascript/blob/83ec173b08bdf18fda805e0d68e0034dbae0eb24/packages/fastify/src/__tests__/withClerkMiddleware.test.ts).

title: Middleware with pre-v1 peerDependencies installs old version of them
body:
I started using Valibot validator middleware and noticed that the installed Valibot is quite old. There are 22 releases between the installed (0.13.1) and the latest (0.30.0) versions.

This is because peer deps are declared with a caret notation and `^0.13.1` doesn't match 0.14.0 and later.

https://github.com/honojs/middleware/blob/c56b22f15ad9203d46b15440bd7764e45d244b99/packages/valibot-validator/package.json#L29-L32

This is particularly problematic when a middleware is installed in a project where its peer deps are already used. An `ERESOLVE` error is issued and you fail to install the middleware:

```console
$ npm install valibot
$ npm install @hono/valibot-validator
npm ERR! code ERESOLVE
npm ERR! ERESOLVE unable to resolve dependency tree
npm ERR!
npm ERR! While resolving: hono-middleware-repro@1.0.0
npm ERR! Found: valibot@0.30.0
npm ERR! node_modules/valibot
npm ERR!   valibot@"^0.30.0" from the root project
npm ERR!
npm ERR! Could not resolve dependency:
npm ERR! peer valibot@"^0.13.1" from @hono/valibot-validator@0.2.2
npm ERR! node_modules/@hono/valibot-validator
npm ERR!   @hono/valibot-validator@"*" from the root project
npm ERR!
npm ERR! Fix the upstream dependency conflict, or retry
npm ERR! this command with --force or --legacy-peer-deps
npm ERR! to accept an incorrect (and potentially broken) dependency resolution.
npm ERR!
npm ERR!
npm ERR! For a full report see:
npm ERR! /Users/ynkt/.npm/_logs/2024-04-06T18_55_32_176Z-eresolve-report.txt

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in: /Users/ynkt/.npm/_logs/2024-04-06T18_55_32_176Z-debug-0.log
```

Semver like `>=0.13.1 <1` would be preferred so that users can have access to Valibot's new features, but I don't have time to investigate if there are incompatibilites that break `@hono/valibot-validator` between 0.13.1 and 0.30.0. Breaking changes might be OK because `@hono/valibot-validator` is pre-v1 as well.

I'd like to hear your opinion on this problem before working on a PR. What do you think?

title: packages/esbuild-transpiler#deno--deno-deploy: transpiled TypeScript served with incorrect MIME type
body:
Following the [esbuild Transpiler Middleware Deno / Deno Deploy](https://github.com/honojs/middleware/tree/c56b22f15ad9203d46b15440bd7764e45d244b99/packages/esbuild-transpiler#deno--deno-deploy) successfully transpiles `/static/*` files but the MIME type is incorrect which prevents browsers from loading them.

```js
await import("http://localhost:8000/static/foo.ts")
```

title: Importing @hono/zod-openapi in cloudflare worker vitest environment fails
body:
Cloudflare recently [announced](https://blog.cloudflare.com/workers-vitest-integration) their new testing integration with vitest to test workers directly in a workers environment.

When trying it out myself I stumbled about this bug caused by `@hono/zod-openapi` because it can't import `@hono/zod-validator`. But if you look closely at the error message you can see that `@hono/zod-openapi` tries to import `@hono/zod-validator` from `.../dist/@hono/zod-validator` but that path is wrong, since dependencies are not located in `dist`.
```
[vpw:inf] Starting isolated runtimes for vitest.config.ts...
workerd/server/server.c++:2789: error: Fallback service failed to fetch module; payload = ; spec = /?specifier=%2FUsers%2F...%2Foapi-bug%2Fnode_modules%2F%40hono%2Fzod-validator%2Fdist%2Fesm%2Findex.js&referrer=%2FUsers%2F...%2Foapi-bug%2Fnode_modules%2F%40hono%2Fzod-openapi%2Fdist%2Findex.mjs
 ❯ test/index.spec.ts (0)

⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯ Failed Suites 1 ⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯

 FAIL  test/index.spec.ts [ test/index.spec.ts ]
Error: No such module "Users/.../oapi-bug/node_modules/@hono/zod-openapi/dist/@hono/zod-validator".
  imported from "Users/.../oapi-bug/node_modules/@hono/zod-openapi/dist/index.mjs"
```

Here is a minimal [repo](https://github.com/JonasHiltl/oapi-bug) to reproduce the bug.
The bug is caused by just importing from `@hono/zod-openapi`, so this is enough
```ts
import { OpenAPIHono } from "@hono/zod-openapi";
import { test } from "vitest";

test("test", () => {
  const app = new OpenAPIHono();
})
```

This smells like an `esm` error to me, but I'm not sure why it searches for the dependency in `dist` 🤷‍♂️

[zod-openapi][feature request] set route specific middleware from zod-openapi createRoute
body:
We love working with hono/zod-openapi and hono in general. We do have a challenge with configuring route-specific middleware in a way that is both maintainable, readable and secure (the last argument being that you make it very difficult for developer to simply forget making an api route secure enough).

Our goal was to support per route a different combination of middleware. such as, but not limited to:
- rate limiting with varying config
-  guard middleware with varying protection levels. For example just check authentication, check tenant (for high-sec multi-tenant systems), system admin level check with fixed ip requirement etcetera. Or simply a route that allows public access.
- The guard level needs to be made explicitly on each route: public, auth, tenant or system level. This way its pretty difficult to forget about it?

You can already create route-specific middleware but you get sort of a duplication of your entire route configuration - if you also use zod-openapi?

Our conclusion was to implement it in the createRoute step, but because this is not supported by `hono/zod-openapi`, we now created an abstraction layer that resolves into createRoute. See an example below and the complete work here: https://github.com/cellajs/cella/blob/a51e182662cbcd3db8575dec4356c78203129013/backend/src/types/common.ts.


```
guard: RouteConfig['guard'];
middlewares: RouteConfig['middlewares'];
```

Our question is if this solution of ours could also be beneficial to others that use hono/zod-openapi and developer using  hono in general. It could improve the flexibility of setting middleware like also superficially discussed in this Twitter thread? https://twitter.com/jullerino/status/1763525247477641688

Or perhaps there are other ways to achieve the same results?

title: feat(zod-openapi): Add `toDoc` function to generate OpenAPI specification files
body:
Introduces a new function called `toDoc` that allows users to generate OpenAPI specification files.

### features:

Accepts a Hono application instance, a file system module, and optional configurations
Supports exporting in JSON or YAML format
Returns an export result object with success status, output directory, generated files, and error (if any)

### Usage:

```ts
import { OpenAPIHono, toDoc } from '@hono/zod-openapi'
import fs from 'fs/promises'

const app = new OpenAPIHono()

// Define routes and schemas...

await exportOpenAPI(app, fs, {
  outDir: './docs',
  format: 'yaml',
  extension: '.yml',
})
```

### Configuration options:

- outDir: Output directory for the generated files (default: './dist')
- format: File format, either 'json' or 'yaml' (default: 'json')
- extension: File extension (default: based on format)

title: [zod-openapi] hono client type inference does not work with a chained route and middleware
body:
Currently `OpenAPIHono` types do not allow to chain `.use(...)` and `.openapi(...)` - even if everything works fine during runtime.

```ts
const app = new OpenAPIHono()
  .use(routeTest.getRoutingPath(), cors())
  .openapi(routeTest, (c) => c.json('test')); // Property 'openapi' does not exist on type 'Hono<Env, {}, "/">'.
```

And the hono client (RPC) does not work as well in this case:

```ts
const client = hc<typeof app>('http://localhost:8787/');
client. // Missing type inference
```

_(see example 1 in the Stackblitz setup)_

This kind of definition should be supported to use hono client (RPC) in larger applications with an OpenAPIHono setup:
https://hono.dev/guides/rpc#using-with-larger-applications

A workaround is type casting:

```ts
const app = (
  new OpenAPIHono()
    .use(routeTest.getRoutingPath(), cors()) as OpenAPIHono // casting from Hono to OpenAPIHono
  )
  .openapi(routeTest, (c) => c.json('test'));

const client = hc<typeof app>('http://localhost:8787/');
client.index.$get() // Type inference works now
```

_(see example 3 in the Stackblitz setup)_

**Setup to reproduce the error:**
https://stackblitz.com/edit/spvrub-hono-zod-openapi?file=src%2Fserver.ts&view=editor

title: Adding Appwrite auth middleware

Appwrite has added Server-Side login as you can see [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jeL4cSovOBA) and [here](https://appwrite.io/docs/products/auth/server-side-rendering)

This middleware also provides 2 helpers for making the process of email and OAuth2 login much easier.

title: fix(oidc-auth): Fix "yarn release" for Yarn v4 / Build ESM only
body:
Hi @yusukebe !
Thanks for releasing `@hono/oidc-auth`!

However, I noticed that there are no `dist/*` files in the npm package for `@hono/oidc-auth@1.0.0`.
This is due to the `yarn release` not executing the `build` script in the `package.json`.
I have fixed the `release` script to address this issue.

Additionally, `yarn publish` was a Yarn v1 command, so I have updated it to be compatible with v4.

Lastly, I noticed that the dependent library, `oauth4webapi`, does not support CommonJS.
As a result, I have updated the `package.json` to only build ESM.

Authorization Header Not Working with Swagger in Hono/Zod-OpenAPI
body: Hello Hono/Zod-OpenAPI Team, I'm encountering an issue with Swagger integration in a route I defined using Hono/Zod-OpenAPI. Specifically, I'm unable to send the "Authorization" header through Swagger's interface. Here's a brief overview of the problem: **Issue Description:** I've defined a route in my Hono application and used Zod-OpenAPI to generate the Swagger documentation. When I try to send a request with an "Authorization" header through Swagger UI, it seems like the header is not included in the request. This issue is preventing me from testing secured endpoints directly from the Swagger UI. **Steps to Reproduce:** Define a route in Hono using Zod-OpenAPI. Add an "Authorization" header requirement in the OpenAPI specification. Attempt to send a request with the "Authorization" header through Swagger UI. **Expected Behavior:** The "Authorization" header should be included in the request, and the endpoint should recognize and validate it. **Actual Behavior:** The "Authorization" header appears to be missing or not sent in the request made from Swagger UI. **Environment:** Hono version: ^3.12.8 Zod-OpenAPI version: ^0.9.6 Node.js version: v20.8.1 For your reference, here is the link to the relevant part of my code in my GitHub repository: [My Project Code](https://github.com/ercumentlacin/hono-todo/blob/main/src/modules/users/routes/userUpdateByIdRoute.ts). I would appreciate any guidance or suggestions on how to resolve this issue. Is this a known problem, or am I missing something in my configuration? Any help would be greatly appreciated. Thank you for your time and assistance. Best regards,

title: Cannot use preprocess and coerce in zValidator.
body:
hono v3.12.6
zValidator v0.1.11
typescript v5.3.2
zod v3.22.4

I get a type error on the zValidator line with the following code.

```
export const app = new Hono()

const route = app.get(
  '/posts/:id',
  zValidator(
    'query',
    z.object({
      page: z.preprocess((input) => parseInt(input), z.number().optional()),
    })
  ),
  (c) => {
    const a = c.req.valid('query').page
    // ...
    return c.json({
      title: 'Night',
      body: 'Time to sleep',
    })
  }
)
```

This is the error message.
```
 TS2769: No overload matches this call.
The last overload gave the following error.
Argument of type
MiddlewareHandler<Env, string, {   in: {     query: {       page?: unknown;     };   };   out: {     query: {       page?: number | undefined;     };   }; }>
is not assignable to parameter of type
H<Env, '/posts/:id', Input, Response & TypedResponse<JSONParsed<{   title: string;   body: string; }>>>
Type
MiddlewareHandler<Env, string, {   in: {     query: {       page?: unknown;     };   };   out: {     query: {       page?: number | undefined;     };   }; }>
is not assignable to type MiddlewareHandler<Env, '/posts/:id', Input>
Types of parameters c and c are incompatible.
Type Context<Env, '/posts/:id', Input> is not assignable to type
Context<Env, string, {   in: {     query: {       page?: unknown;     };   };   out: {     query: {       page?: number | undefined;     };   }; }>
Type Partial<ValidationTargets> | undefined is not assignable to type { query: { page?: unknown; }; }
Type undefined is not assignable to type { query: { page?: unknown; }; }
types.d.ts(152, 5): The last overload is declared here.
```

And I can't even use coerce.
I think each query value is defined string | undefined, so type mismatch occurred by after preprocess value.

title: Type Error when trying to validate 'params' with zValidator - Types of parameters 'c' and 'c' are incompatible
body:
I might be missing something here but I can't seem to work my way around this type error when I try to use zValidator with my params schema.

```ts
// A snippet from my code
const racesParams = z.object({ seasonId: z.string() })

app.get('/season/:seasonId/races', zValidator('param', racesParams), async (c) => { // <-- type error with validator usage
  const { seasonId } = c.req.valid('param')

  return c.json(await getRaces(seasonId), 200)
})
```
I get this type error complaining about my usage of zValidator.
```
No overload matches this call.
  The last overload gave the following error.
    Argument of type 'MiddlewareHandler<Env, string, { in: { param: { seasonId: string; }; }; out: { param: { seasonId: string; }; }; }>' is not assignable to parameter of type 'H<Env, "/season/:seasonId/races", {}, HandlerResponse<any>>'.
      Type 'MiddlewareHandler<Env, string, { in: { param: { seasonId: string; }; }; out: { param: { seasonId: string; }; }; }>' is not assignable to type 'MiddlewareHandler<Env, "/season/:seasonId/races", {}>'.
        Types of parameters 'c' and 'c' are incompatible.
          Type 'Context<Env, "/season/:seasonId/races", {}>' is not assignable to type 'Context<Env, string, { in: { param: { seasonId: string; }; }; out: { param: { seasonId: string; }; }; }>'.
            Property '#private' in type 'Context' refers to a different member that cannot be accessed from within type 'Context'.ts(2769)
types.d.ts(152, 5): The last overload is declared here.
```

I'm using bun 1.0.22 and my package.json looks like
```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "bun run --hot src/index.ts",
    "integration:test": "./scripts/run-integration-tests.sh",
    "migrate": "bun run src/migrate.ts"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@hono/zod-validator": "^0.1.11",
    "drizzle-orm": "^0.29.3",
    "hono": "^3.12.3",
    "postgres": "^3.4.3",
    "zod": "^3.22.4"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@faker-js/faker": "^8.3.1",
    "bun-types": "^1.0.7",
    "drizzle-kit": "^0.20.10",
    "moment": "^2.30.1",
    "postgres-interval": "^4.0.1"
  }
}
```

I've seen a few issues with similar struggles but nothing I could find seems to demo the usage of validating 'params' or fix my issue.

title: Bun TypeScript Transpiler Middleware
body:
Analogous to the [`esbuild transpiler`](https://github.com/honojs/middleware/tree/main/packages/esbuild-transpiler) middleware that supports Node, Deno and Cloudflare, I propose the implementation of a `bun transpiler` middleware. I'd be happy to create a PR.

Example how it would be used:

```javascript
import { Hono } from 'hono'
import { serveStatic } from 'hono/bun'
import { bunTranspiler } from '@hono/bun-transpiler'

const app = new Hono()

app.get('/static/:scriptName{.+.tsx?}', bunTranspiler())
app.get('/static/*', serveStatic({ root: './' }))

export default app
```

title: Adding hono/prometheus middleware
body:
Fixes https://github.com/honojs/hono/issues/263

As suggested in [this comment](https://github.com/honojs/hono/issues/263#issuecomment-1193129541), I'm adding this to the `honojs/middleware` repository instead of the main one as a third-party middleware.

I've tried to come up with sensible configuration options and default values based on my previous experiences with [express-prom-bundle](https://www.npmjs.com/package/express-prom-bundle) and [koa-prometheus](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@uswitch/koa-prometheus).

title: fix(firebase-auth): export esm
body:
In this PR, make Firebase Auth Middleware exports `esm` formatted package.

In Issue #335, `hono` was using `esm` and `@hono/firebase-auth` was using `cjs` so they did not reference the same `HTTPException` and the `res instanceof HTTPException` was not working properly. By using `@hono/firebase-auth` with this PR, both will use `esm` and the error will be gone.

Fixes #335

title: Firebase Auth returns 500s
body:
Hi, when using the example for `@hono/firebase-auth`, a Hono server returns `500 Internal Server Error` instead of the expected proper error codes. My reproduction case is the one provided in the `@hono/firebase-auth` README, ```ts import { Hono } from 'hono' import { VerifyFirebaseAuthConfig, VerifyFirebaseAuthEnv, verifyFirebaseAuth, getFirebaseToken, } from '@hono/firebase-auth' const config: VerifyFirebaseAuthConfig = { projectId: 'lessgames-73fa6', } const app = new Hono<{ Bindings: VerifyFirebaseAuthEnv }>() app.use('*', verifyFirebaseAuth(config)) app.get('/hello', (c) => { const idToken = getFirebaseToken(c) return c.json(idToken) }) export default app ``` Where I've also defined `PUBLIC_JWK_CACHE_KV` and `PUBLIC_JWK_CACHE_KEY` in my `wrangler.toml`. Though I have `node_compat` enabled as well, this issue exists regardless. Running `wrangler dev src/index.ts` and hitting the `/` endpoint with zero Authorization provides the following:
Wrangler Remote Error

``` Your worker has access to the following bindings: - KV Namespaces: - PUBLIC_JWK_CACHE_KV: 042451a9970b4eadb0bb59fcba417223 - R2 Buckets: - MY_BUCKET: lessgames-preview - Vars: - PUBLIC_JWK_CACHE_KEY: "jwk-key" [wrangler:inf] Ready on http://localhost:8787 Total Upload: 147.25 KiB / gzip: 30.74 KiB [wrangler:inf] GET / 500 Internal Server Error (1683ms) Error at Array. (file:////.wrangler/tmp/dev-yqZ34O/index.js:2789:17) at Hono2.dispatch (file:////.wrangler/tmp/dev-yqZ34O/index.js:3937:38) at Hono2.fetch (file:////.wrangler/tmp/dev-yqZ34O/index.js:3777:19) { res: Response, status: 400, stack: Error at Array. (file:////.wrangler/tmp/dev-6ovetY/index.js:3777:19) } ```

--- | Package | Version | |--------|-------- | `hono` | `3.11.12` | | `@hono/firebase-auth` | `1.3.3` | | `wrangler` | `3.22.1` |

title: feat: introduce React Renderer Middleware
body:
This PR introduces the 'React Renderer Middleware'.

It is similar to the JSX Renderer Middleware in Hono's core, but it uses React. This might be used in Sonik or other meta-frameworks built on Hono. React supports not only server-side but also client-side rendering. Therefore, you can use it in a different way compared to Hono's JSX. Additionally, you can use a lot libraries available in React's ecosystem.

title: Test Suite in OpenAPI Hono Won't Compile
body:
Running Jest on the original Hono works fine

```ts
import { Hono } from "hono";
```

title: fix: redirect url for github apps

OAuth apps can't have multiple callback URLs, but GitHub Apps can.

As such, we want to make sure we call back to the same location for GitHub apps and not the first configured callbackURL in the app config.

cc @yusukebe @monoald

But swagger-ui-dist can recieve more extra options as `[key:string]: any`

so we have to support more extra fields written in [swagger-ui-dist configuration docs](https://swagger.io/docs/open-source-tools/swagger-ui/usage/configuration/)

[note]
In #265, @scarf005 support `persistAuthorization`

title: swagger-ui: support `persistAuthorization`
body:
[`persistAuthorization`](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-ui/blob/d3bb64f1de150ea1ff677accf705c9ce0ae9fe85/flavors/swagger-ui-react/README.md?plain=1#L161) allows credentials to be stored in localstorage. this is useful for quickly refreshing and testing changes in API with swagger UI. ```ts new Hono() .get("/openapi.json", (c) => c.json(doc)) .get("/openapi", swaggerUI({ url: "/openapi.json", persistAuthorization: true })) ``` however, this doesn't type checks and will not render properly, ```ts new Hono() .get("/openapi.json", (c) => c.json(doc)) .get("/openapi", swaggerUI({ url: "/openapi.json", manuallySwaggerUIHtml: (asset) => /*html*/`
${asset.css.map((url) => ``)} ${asset.js.map((url) => ``)}
` })) ``` while this works. I'm interested in opening PR.

body:
Hello,

I'm trying to use the recently released UI Middleware with OpenAPI & Zod. I simply implemented the provided [example](https://github.com/honojs/middleware/tree/main/packages/swagger-ui#with-openapihono-usage)
```ts
import { OpenAPIHono, createRoute, z } from '@hono/zod-openapi'
import { swaggerUI } from '@hono/swagger-ui'

const app = new OpenAPIHono()

app.get('/ui', swaggerUI({url: '/doc' }))

app.doc('/doc', {
  info: {
    title: 'An API',
    version: 'v1'
  },
  openapi: '3.1.0'
})

export default app
```

[firebase-auth] Is there support for multiple environments (projectIds)?
body:
Currently in @hono/firebase-auth, projectId is passed to the middleware setter via a config object. Other values are passed via environment and internally set in the MiddlewareHandler. I'm not sure how/where I'd be able to wrap/inject the PROJECT_ID environment variable to the config object and the `app.use("*", verifyFirebaseAuth(config));` middleware setter. 

Isn't this required to support multiple Firebase projects (1 project_id per environment like staging, prod)?

https://github.com/honojs/middleware/blob/d2398a4c9091c3ff1497a72733242517af215906/packages/firebase-auth/src/index.ts#L49

Internally, would most of it be handled if the above line was changed to: `config.projectId ?? c.env.PROJECT_ID` ?

I'd love to open a PR if this makes sense, or would appreciate guidance around proper usage if it's currently supported a different way.

title: Hono / GraphQL / Pothos integration issues
body:
# Full repro, including tests located here: https://github.com/armstrong-pv/hono-pothos-issue-repro

First of all, I'm really enjoying using Hono - great job on speed and simplicity 👏. I initially started with plain REST, but then moved on to using GraphQL using the middleware you provide. [Pothos](https://github.com/hayes/pothos) is a type safe GraphQL schema builder which I'd really like to use together with Hono, but I'm having some issues trying to get them to work together. 
1. Context Propagation
I can get the context from the pipeline to go to a root resolver, but not to go to individual resolvers, e.g. for mutations.
2. When I try to use `authScopes` for resolvers, the GraphQL processing returns this error: "Invalid value used as weak map key". I raised an issue in the Pothos repo here: https://github.com/hayes/pothos/issues/1064, and the author thinks it's related to propagating the context object, so if 1 is solved, then this should be solved also.
3.  It would be nice to opt out of the GraphQL error handling, e.g. by returning a plain old 401 http code, but everything gets wrapped in a GraphQL error. Not sure if there's anything that can be done about this.

I'm using Cloudflare Workers and it's not trivial to get everything up and running, so I have created a full repro of these issues, along with tests that demonstrate them at this repo: https://github.com/armstrong-pv/hono-pothos-issue-repro

There is a readme which covers setting everything up and running the tests: https://github.com/armstrong-pv/hono-pothos-issue-repro/blob/main/README.md.
It's pretty straightforward:
````
npm install
npm run tests
````
If you want to run in dev mode:
````
npm run dev
````

Many thanks!

title: raise error instead of reponse null and 400 (firebase auth)
body:
Hi,
I was trying to make this work with deno runtime, but I guess might be an issue across all edge networks.

We need to set the middleware for all routes. Reason, on my home page if the user is signed in , (already has a valid authorization) then I need to show Logout Button. 

```
// set middleware
app.use('*', verifyFirebaseAuth(config))
```

Now, let say my root route.
```
app.get('/', (c) => {
 return c.text('Hello from home')
})
````

because the middle ware is called on each route invocation and we try to 

```
 const authorization = c.req.headers.get(config.AuthorizationHeaderKey) 
```

if the authorization is null, we are sending null response with 400. This results in home page also not being shown. So I think, this behavior is not proper or I might be missing something.

title: feat(zod-openapi): implement Zod schema validation on response
body:
Hi, here is my try to implement a fix for #181.

Because this (might be) a breaking change, and not all people might want to use the feature, I implemented them behind the flag `strictStatusCode?: boolean`, `strictResponse?: boolean` so we can enable the feature when initializing `OpenAPIHono`

- `strictStatusCode`: basically we read from `RouterConfig` about the list of possible status codes, and just return an error whenever the schema doesn't contain the status code.
- `strictResponse` basically matches the status code, get that status code's schema, then do `safeParseAsync` against the data.

Honestly I still don't know the best practice in Hono on how throw and/or modify the response (and if this is a minor or major bump). I hope the tests can make it more clear though. Thank you

If we're okay with this approach, I can add docs to the README.

Another option would be to export the types for `.openapi` and allow someone to create an `applyDefaultHook` similar to what I've shown here: https://tsplay.dev/NnMyaw

title: issue with Path Parameter Definition in Swagger using @hono/zod-openapi
body:
# Issue Description:

![unnamed](https://github.com/honojs/middleware/assets/117732586/1710db99-2c7d-4a43-8ea3-30c86cb7755a)

When following the example provided by @hono/zod-openapi and using the path parameter syntax '{id}' in Swagger to define an endpoint path like '/users/{id}', an issue arises where the defined endpoint cannot be found. This results in a 404 error when testing the endpoint with Postman or any. However, when the path is manually changed to '/users/:id', the endpoint functions correctly.

# Steps to Reproduce:

Utilize the example provided by @hono/zod-openapi for defining an endpoint path with a path parameter using '{id}' syntax.
Try to access the defined endpoint using Postman or any other API testing tool.

# Expected Behavior:
The endpoint defined with the '{id}' syntax should be successfully recognized and accessible both in Swagger documentation and when tested.

# Actual Behavior:
When using the defined '{id}' path parameter syntax in Swagger, the endpoint cannot be found, and a 404 error is returned when testing the endpoint api call. However, changing the path parameter syntax to '/users/:id' makes the endpoint work as expected.

# Additional Information:

This issue seems to be specific to the use of the '{id}' path parameter syntax in Swagger, as manually changing it to '/users/:id' in both the Swagger documentation and the testing tool resolves the issue.
When modifying the OpenAPI documentation directly to use '/users/{id}' and accessing the endpoint, it functions correctly.
It appears that the inconsistency lies in how the '{id}' syntax is interpreted when used within the Swagger documentation.

# Environment Details:

Library: @hono/zod-openapi
OpenAPI Definition: (Provide the relevant OpenAPI definition excerpt where the endpoint is defined)
Testing Tool: Postman (or specify the testing tool used)
API Endpoint Path: '/users/{id}'
HTTP Method: GET (or specify the method)

title: feat(qwik-city): adapt to v1.2.0 API and refine dependencies
body:
Hi everyone,

The main focus of this PR is to adapt to the new `ServerRequestEvent` signature introduced in [qwik-city v1.2.0](https://github.com/BuilderIO/qwik/releases/tag/v1.2.0) by  https://github.com/BuilderIO/qwik/pull/4433

v1.1.5: https://github.com/BuilderIO/qwik/blob/v1.1.5/packages/qwik-city/middleware/request-handler/types.ts#L16-L24C2
v1.2.0: https://github.com/BuilderIO/qwik/blob/v1.2.0/packages/qwik-city/middleware/request-handler/types.ts#L31

To achieve this, the peerDependencies have been updated to target qwik-city v1.2.0 or higher. 

Additionally, the Hono version was previously pinned at 3.1.5, which was unnecessarily restrictive and forced middleware users to stick with that specific version. To provide more flexibility, the requirement has been changed to Hono v3.1.5 or higher.

I've also done some minor refactoring inspired by the implementation in [qwik-city's middleware](https://github.com/BuilderIO/qwik/blob/09e55521deb9cab5e954b7cbf55b3e26d49de799/packages/qwik-city/middleware/cloudflare-pages/index.ts). 

Note: The newly introduced `getClientConn` function may need to address use cases where the implementation varies depending on the deployment environment, such as whether it's running on Cloudflare Workers or Deno. This middleware doesn't currently address these scenarios, I think it may require some additional planning and consideration.

Thank you for developing this wonderful software; I'm looking forward to contributing more in the future.

title: Issue with type mismatch when using zValidator middleware with Hono
body:
Hello :wave:, I hope you're doing well! I've encountered an issue with a type mismatch when trying to use the zValidator middleware from the @hono/zod-validator package with Hono. The error occurs when passing the middleware to app.post().

First, I'd like to thank you for creating such a great library :pray:. Here's the code snippet to reproduce the issue:

```typescript
import { zValidator } from '@hono/zod-validator';
import { z } from 'zod';
const app = new Hono<{ Bindings: Bindings; Variables: { sentry: Toucan; tenantId: string; } }>();

const postBalanceValidator = zValidator('form', z.object({ amount: z.number() }));
app.post(
  '/balance',
  postBalanceValidator, // <-- ERROR HERE
  (c) => addBalance(c)
);
```
The TypeScript compiler reports the following error:

```
この呼び出しに一致するオーバーロードはありません。
  前回のオーバーロードにより、次のエラーが発生しました。
    型 'MiddlewareHandler<Env, string, { in: { form: { amount: number; }; }; out: { form: { amount: number; }; }; }>' の引数を型 'H<{ Bindings: Bindings; Variables: { sentry: Toucan;tenantId: string; } ; }, string, Input, {}>' のパラメーターに割り当てることはできません。
      型 'MiddlewareHandler<Env, string, { in: { form: { amount: number; }; }; out: { form: { amount: number; }; }; }>' を型 'MiddlewareHandler<{ Bindings: Bindings; Variables: { sentry: Toucan;tenantId: string; } ; }, string, Input>' に割り当てることはできません。
        パラメーター 'c' および 'c' は型に互換性がありません。
          型 'Context<{ Bindings: Bindings; Variables: { sentry: Toucan;tenantId: string; } ; }, string, Input>' を型 'Context<Env, string, { in: { form: { amount: number; }; }; out: { form: { amount: number; }; }; }>' に割り当てることはできません。
            型 'Env' を型 '{ Bindings: Bindings; Variables: { sentry: Toucan;tenantId: string; } ; }' に割り当てることはでき

```

Your help would be greatly appreciated! Thank you in advance :smiley:.

title: [zod-validator] `c.req.valid("json")` returning `never`
Denoify to DNT
body:
Hi! I was planning on making my own framework as I found most frameworks having issues with edge environments & this framework is awesome so far! So first of all great work!!

As I started looking at the packages, I realized that denoify was being used to convert the package from an npm module to a deno module. Deno has an official package that does the opposite & seems to have better support, you can find it [here](https://github.com/denoland/dnt).

I was wondering if it would make sense to reverse it to go from Deno to NPM instead of NPM to Deno?
